citeinfo.title: Downhole Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Observations; Alaska, 2014
Evidence for nonuniform permafrost degradation after fire in boreal landscapes

pubinfo.publish: Journal of Geophysical Research - Earth Surface

descript.abstract: >Fire can be a significant driver of permafrost change in boreal landscapes, altering the availability of soil carbon and nutrients that have important implications for future climate and ecological succession. However, not all landscapes are equally susceptible to fire-induced change. As fire frequency is expected to increase in the high latitudes, methods to understand the vulnerability and resilience of different landscapes to permafrost degradation are needed. Geophysical and other field observations reveal details of both near-surface (&lt;1 m) and deeper (&gt;1 m) impacts of fire on permafrost along 11 transects that span burned-unburned boundaries in different landscape settings within interior Alaska. Data collected along the 11 transect locations include: electrical resistivity tomography (ERT), downhole nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), active layer thickness (ALT), organic layer thickness (OLT), and plant species cover. These geospatial datasets are the foundation for the journal article, "Evidence for non-uniform permafrost degradation after fire in boreal landscapes", published in the Journal of Geophysical Research - Earth Surface.
descript.purpose: Data were collected to quantify the below-ground impacts of fire on permafrost in boreal landscapes.

spdom.descgeog: Interior Alaska, near Fairbanks and southeast along the Alaska Highway towards Canada

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: There is no guarantee concerning the accuracy of the data. Any user who modifies the data is obligated to describe the types of modifications they perform. Data have been checked to ensure the accuracy. If any errors are detected, please notify the originating office. The U.S. Geological Survey strongly recommends that careful attention be paid to the metadata file associated with these data. Acknowledgment of the U.S. Geological Survey would be appreciated in products derived from these data. User specifically agrees not to misrepresent the data, nor to imply that changes made were approved or endorsed by the U.S. Geological Survey. Please refer to http://www.usgs.gov/privacy.html for the USGS disclaimer.

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted.

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted.
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the data set has not been conducted.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.

method.methdesc: Locations of NMR observations were collected in the field using handheld GPS (Ashtech MobileMapper100). Coordinates were converted to a shapefile.

procstep.procdesc: Locations of NMR observations were collected in the field using handheld GPS (Ashtech MobileMapper100). Coordinates were converted to a shapefile.

enttyp.enttypd: Location information associated with the NMR observation sites.

attr.attrdef: Unique identifier of GPS survey site for NMR observation

Unique site names that correspond to collected and processed data (NMR).
